issue.title: `as_awaitable(expr, p)` does not define semantics of call if `p` is not an lvalue

discussion.p:
The wording in p7 defines the semantics of a call to `as_awaitable(expr, p)` where `p` is an lvalue. However, it does not specify what the behaviour is if `p` is not an lvalue.
We should probably say that `as_awaitable(expr, p)` is ill-formed if `p` is not an lvalue.
Set priority to 2 after reflector poll.

blockquote.p: -7- `as_awaitable` is a customization point object. For subexpressions `expr` and `p` where `p` is an lvalue, `Expr` names the type `decltype((expr))` and `Promise` names the type decay_t<decltype((p))>, if `p` is not an lvalue, `as_awaitable(expr, p)` is ill-formed, otherwise `as_awaitable(expr, p)` is expression-equivalent to, except that the evaluations of `expr` and `p` are indeterminately sequenced:
